Q1: Dear Faculty, Please use the following survey to evaluate the student's performance in Clinical Semi...
Q2_1: Pick from the dropdown list below the student presentation you attended and are evaluating:-Presentation:
Q3_2: Presentation Style-Thorough eye contact/ minimal reliance on notes
Q3_3: Presentation Style-Displayed professionalism/ poise/ confidence/ lacked distracting mannerisms
Q3_4: Presentation Style-Material presented at the appropriate level for the audience
Q5_1: Instructional Materials-Slides and handout were clear/easy to read
Q5_2: Instructional Materials-Slides and handout  are devoid of spelling and grammatical errors
Q5_3: Instructional Materials-Provided orientation to charts/graphs/pictures/diagrams (if applicable)
Q5_4: Instructional Materials-Cites appropriate references/correct referencing style and emphasizes primary literature
Q7_1: Overall Presentation Content-Introduction, interest in topic, and outline/objectives described
Q7_2: Overall Presentation Content-Defines purpose/controversy of seminar topic clearly
Q7_3: Overall Presentation Content-Objectives clear and useful for self assessment
Q7_4: Overall Presentation Content-Appropriate background information was provided
Q7_5: Overall Presentation Content-Well organized presentations and smooth transitions (appropriate 'flow')
Q8: Additional comments regarding overall presentation content:
Q9_1: Presentation of Clinical Data-Presented concise objectives, methodology and treatment for each study
Q9_2: Presentation of Clinical Data-Outcome measures were stated and described, and appropriateness was explained
Q9_3: Presentation of Clinical Data-Presented key trial results with corresponding statistical analysis
Q9_4: Presentation of Clinical Data-Student is able to determine if sample size and power is appropriate (if applicable)
Q9_5: Presentation of Clinical Data-Withdrawals and dropouts are accounted for (if applicable)
Q9_6: Presentation of Clinical Data-Provided a detailed & thoughtful analysis of study strengths and limitations
Q10: Additional comments regarding presentation of clinical data:
Q11_1: Conclusions-Conclusions are supported by data presented in the seminar
Q11_2: Conclusions-Clinical importance and application of the study is discussed
Q11_3: Conclusions-Provided specific recommendations for clinical pharmacy practice
Q11_4: Conclusions-Discussed the role of the pharmacist and/or impact to the profession of pharmacy in regards to the use of the treatment
Q13_1: Question Answer Session-Succinctly, yet thoroughly answered audience questions
Q13_2: Question Answer Session-Encouraged questions and interaction with the audience
Q14: Additional comments regarding the question answer session:
Q15_1: Overall Knowledge Base-Demonstrated knowledge of subject beyond the facts presented in the seminar
Q15_2: Overall Knowledge Base-Student is able to distinguish the difference between clinical and statistical significance
Q15_3: Overall Knowledge Base-Student is able to look beyond the author's conclusions and offer insight into the overall study results
Q15_4: Overall Knowledge Base-Student is able to discuss conclusions in the context of previous research and in comparison to current practice/therapy
Q15_5: Overall Knowledge Base-Student is able to think on his/her feet. May theorize if not sure of answer, but identifies answer as such
Q16: Additional comments regarding overall knowledge base:

Q4: Raymond did a nice job with his presentation style.  He clearly appeared to have practiced his presentation multiple times.  It seemed very polished.
Q6: Instructional materials were put together very well.  They utilized good headings and facilitated good flow of information.
Q8: Overall presentation content was good.  Raymond had a good statement of his interest in the topic.  He used good leadning questions to the audience, for example, "Does anyone know what Tranexamic acid is?" to introduce the topic and the controversy.
Q10: Raymond put much critical thought into the study design, methodologies, results and statistical analysis.  It was clear that he did not exercise blanket acceptance of the author's description of these items.  As an audience member, I had full confidence that Raymond understood and thoroughly analyzed the studies.
Q12: Raymond did an excellent job of extrapolating the literature analysis into his own conclusions.  I liked that he inquired with the audience regarding a "rank order" of where to place rFVIIa in the therapy alternatives.
Q14: Raymond, both encouraged and responded to questions in a very professional manner.
Q16: Previously stated, Raymond did an excellent job in demonstrating his knowledge base.
Q19: This was a very well done seminar.  Raymond has excellent presentation skills.  He showed a great level of maturity, responsibility, and preparation for this seminar.

Q4: Angela did not seem very comfortable with the information on the slides.  She would start speaking toward the audience, but with each slide she quickly looked back toward the slide.  It seem most often that she was reading directly from the slide.
Q6: Angela slides were acceptable and included a few graphics.  The handout was incredibly difficult to follow and turned out to be distracting and time consuming to find information.  The handout had pretty good headings, but, as an opportunity for improvement, would suggest using more bulleted lists and graphics in the handout.  There was a pretty good slide that had venn diagrams, that was helpful for understanding the background information.  That could be included in the handout.  The font on the slides could be made larger.  Some of the slides only had a few lines of text, but the font was kept small.
Q8: Overall, I think more practice would be a learning opportunity for the future.  At times, Angela seemed unsure of the content.  Additional practice facilitates familiarity with the content and confidence in the presenter.  I think this has the makings of a very good seminar presentation.  There was a reasonable controversy, but as pointed out in audience questions, the turn around time of the lab result and the relative cost of the lab test are key factors that would need to be included in the controversy.
Q10: Angela did a good job listing out the various study design elements, methodologies, and statistical analysis, however, her own critical analysis of these items seemed on the weak side.  As an audience member, I have confidence she can pick these items out of a published study, but would like to have learned more of her opinion as to whether the elements in the study were appropriate.
Q12: Again, Angela has great potential with this seminar topic, however, the apparent lack of practice and lessened critical analysis, seemed to take away some of the shine from the presentation.
Q14: Angela did an appropriate job to encourage audience questions.
Q16: Stated in previous comments, but Angela appeared to struggle in this area.  I think she has the capability to be a very good presenter, but the key is advance preparation and practice.
Q19: Overall, seminar was acceptable, but near the lowest level of expectations.  Not sure if there were other factors that were interfering, but her biggest opportunity for improvement is in the preparation phase for seminar.

Q4: I think your pace, etc was excellent. You really have a very pleasant presentation style. My only recommendation for improvement is to consider using the mic. You were audible in the back row, but perhaps on the quiet side.
Q6: Your materials were well done. Be careful to orient the audience to the axes on graphs.
Q8: I thought you did an excellent job setting up your presentation. Your background information was really strong. I would consider spending just a few more moments on the drugs to manage PD. That slide went by pretty quickly.  Your presentation flowed well, and you did a great job managing your time. Keep in mind that students typically ask fewer questions, so if you presented at a state meeting or such, you may find you run over if you pause too many times in the middle of you rpresentation for questions.
Q10: I thought you did a really nice job not just presenting the studies, but providing your interpretation of limitations as you went.
Q12: I think you had specific recommendations, but may have been stronger if you could have addressed questions regarding alternative therapies as well.
Q14: You encouraged audience questions, but sometimes struggled to answer the question. While it is ok to say you don't know, reviewing your background material the week or so before your presentation may be helpful.
Q16: You seemed knowledgabel on the topic; however, framing your recommendations in terms of current practice could have been stronger.
Q19: Overall, you did an excellent job!

Q4: I thought your pace was good. During the presentation, I was not sure if you were feeling ill, but your demeanor suggested that you were feeling down or had low energy, or that you just wanted to be done. Make sure you maintain a positive tone until the end. I think this is where the student comments on presentation style came from.
Q6: I thought your slides were very clear and easy to read. Your handout was well done as well, but perhaps a little wordy. I agree with the suggestion to put a page number on the bones to direct the audience to the correct section. In general I would say to rely less on the handout and to make sure you present all of the informaiton needed to draw conclusions.
Q8: I thought your background information was especially strong and established the controversy and importance of understanding this information.
Q10: I thought you did a really nice job in analyzing the trials and pointing out that even thought the results were statistically significant, they weren't necessarily clinically relevant.
Q12: I think you did a nice job with tconclusion. My only suggestion to make it stronger is to focus on the impact decreasing SREs would have on QOL.
Q14: I think you did a nice job with the questions you had. I am not sure you really encouraged additional questions.
Q16: I think this was the biggest strength of your seminar. You really were able to draw your own conclusions and even stated that you chenged your opinion after reviewing the data.
Q19: I think you did a really nice job overall. In terms of future seminars, I would say watch your energy level and how that affects your audience.

Q4: Excellent eye contact with audience; excellent use of gestures to enhance conversationalism of the seminar versus audience; PLEASE do NOT chew gum during your seminar!!!!  It is a huge distraction, less professional, and makes the seminar far less formal. Volume was muted at the start and it was difficult to hear seminar from back of room; this improved as Lacie warmed up to the audience.
Q6: Lacie's slides showed that she did alot of preparation work to plan, organize and design the slides. Slides were easy to read and the audience was easily oriented to them. Be sure to cite other resources during course of seminar regarding demographics and other stats (many interesting ones were presented).  The studies were cited but this is an obvious expectation.
Q8: Introduction flowed smoothly.  Good transitional flow into the psych drug section (prior to the studies).  Lacie had a well thought -out outline and all pieces seemed to fit into the puzzle!  Nice work.
Q10: Pathophysiology of PD and PDD was presented in an easy to understand manner and I really have to compliment Lacie on demonstrating a solid knowledge base on this science.  The information was shared with the audience in a very thoughtful manner.
Q12: Lacie's conclusions were based on minimal data, and she noted this deficiency. I am not sure that I would have come to the same conclusions since there are 1-2 studies (heterogenous at best on various levels) examining PDD and the other study involved more psychotic tendencies.  It's kind of like trying to draw conclusions from a basket of apples and oranges.  The 3rd study involved patients who had a caregiver at least 3 days a week.  That means then for patients who did not have a caregiver every day, that their dementia may have not been severe and that they could still carry on some routine duties.  I think the studies could have used even more scrutiny and Lacie may have been abit nice to the given authors.
Q14: Lacie did a very nice job handling audience questions and seemed at ease.  She also had various opportunities during the seminar to ask questions which was welcomed by the audience.  Nice job.
Q16: Lacie has a solid knowledge base on PDD and PD.  I think future improvements for a seminar would include tapping local providers who care for patients with dementia to obtain their perspective(s) versus these medications and their experiences. The seminars tend to be steeped in academic evidence with little knowledge of what practitioners are actually doing in practice. This would be an element to improve for future seminars as a practicing pharmacist.  Nice job, overall.
Q19: Thank you for a well prepared, organized and delivered seminar.  Topics involving our elderly patients and how pharmacists can be a part of that care is always heartening.  Thank you for this seminar.

Q4: Sierra appeared rather nervous at start of  seminar with a muted voice which was difficult to hear from back of room. Eye contact was spent mainly on slides and occasionally looked at audience. Several times thru the seminar, she would sigh.  Please do not sigh during a presentation because it makes the speaker seem less credible, like one can't wait for the seminar to be done (true, I know that is what every speaker wants but that is not the goal of seminar) and really is nonprofessional. Material was presented at a level understandable to the audience (which was also noted by students in the audience).  Avoid distracting comments like "you know what I mean" to the audience given the formal nature of the seminar.
Q6: Slides were easy to read for the most part.  I would recommend increasing the font size slightly so one does not have to work at reading the slides.  Try to cite more authorities for demographics, etc during the initial part of seminar (prior to the studies) because this move threads more evidence to back up the statements.
Q8: Interest in topic was provided to audience. Objectives were clear except for objective #4.  "Understand the outlined pharmacist's role".....please complete the thought by including setting/controversy for this role.  It is too broad as stated and not directed. Background was appropriate and aided audience understanding of the given topic.  Slide which listed the 3 cancer study topics was on the screen very briefly.  As a listener watching the speaker, I had little time to grasp the contents of that slide.   Also,  I would make it more clear to the audience WHY the given studies were being presented.  Give the audience a better feel for the breadth of that literature and why these are the important studies to be aware. Transitional flow between studies was abit choppy.  One way to improve upon this criticism is to think of how study #2 will build on study #1; how study #3 will build on study #2 rather than just jumping into each study.
Q10: Sierra did a nice job to present each study regarding the pertinent elements and did so in an easily understood manner. She emphasized followup parameters. Slides were consistently and appropriately highlighted regarding important take-home points for the audience.  She made an important discovery that pain control with outside agents like narcotics and NSAIDs was not adequately discussed by the authors and is a huge criticism of the studies.
Q12: Sierra made thoughtful recommendations for the impact of the pharmacist in the management of pain with agents like ZA.  Within the "overall conclusions" section, Sierra made it clear to the audience the role of ZA in pain control of bony mets and ZA's role in therapy for these patients.  This enabled the audience to leave the seminar room with a grip on how ZA would potentially impact their practice settings and patients.
Q14: Sierra seemed abit timid to answer questions and this likely stems from nervousness and should improve with more opportunities for public speaking. She was able to answer the questions, but the style of answers tended to be muted and difficult to hear.  To help the nerve element, stepping away from the podium, & using hand gestures can help to unleash the nerves and loosen up.
Q16: Sierra did alot of work on this seminar and provided thoughtful analysis on the topic.  I would recommend that for future seminars and/or talks to also make it more clear to the audience how local providers utilize such drugs.  I did not really get a feel for her experience at Huntsman.  This information can add to the sharing of the speaker's interest in the topic and tie the seminar together as a package.  This can improve with more speaking opportunities.
Q19: Sierra presented an organized, well-planned seminar.  The delivery of the seminar needs more work to calm nerves and refine other points as mentioned earlier. Sierra was very respectful of her audience and provided many opportunities for questions to be asked.  I enjoyed the seminar and was actually delighted that the speaker did not necessarily coincide with the conclusions of each author.  Thank you Sierra for a very informative seminar.

Q4: Professional presentation style, good projection to the back of the room.  The flow only stalled a bit when too much time was spent on a particular slide, maybe too much information of one or two slides.  Great plug for Blanding that broke the ice.
Q6: The slides were easy to read for the most part.  On or two of the data tables were too small and too complicated to read, the data could have been highlighted or replotted to make it easier for the audience.
Q8: The use of the timeline in opioid use was great, a good hook for the audience.  The Controversy was very well defined, but it would have been more effective if it were up in the first few slides instead of 14 minutes in.
Q10: Good presentation of clinical data, should stay away from big data tables with small print in the future.
Q12: The conclusions were justified, unfortunately in a situation when even the true rate for the problem is in doubt, and where the resolution will require input from the doctor and e the patient  it is tough to make firm recommendations
Q14: Excellent Q and A at the end.  The topic generated lots of discussion.  I think many in the audience wanted the opportunity to ask questions during the talk so time for that should be planned into the presentation.
Q16: The seminarian demonstrated good command of the material during the Q&A.
Q19: A couple small changes would have improved the experience for the audience but overall a well done seminar.

Q4: Professional presentation style, minimal reliance on notes, very few misstatements.
Q6: The slides were easy to read and easy on the eye.  One or two of the data tables were too small, and a couple of the slides were a bit wordy, it was appreciated when the data were replottted in the second study!
Q8: Well organized, good intro and good job putting the controversy forward in the talk.
Q10: Good presentation of clinical results, some in the audience may have wanted a bit more on strengths versus the weaknesses but it was well done with in the time limitations.
Q12: I liked the Future Studies slide, it made folks think about what data are missing before other recommendations could be made.
Q14: Did a great job answering questions and demonstrated a broad command of the topic.  Three studies is too long to go with out questions, though.  A lot of the audience enthusiasm and spontaneity of interactions is lost.  Need to schedule a brief time for questions at the transitions.
Q16: Seminarian demonstrated good command of the topic.
Q19: Good presentation on an interesting topic, remember to schedule a little time for audience interactions throughout.

Q4: Your pace was a bit fast, whenever I looked down at the handout, I looked back up to find I had missed something. Your projection was nice, I couldn't tell whether the mic was working or not, but could hear you clearly. Occasionally you'd trail off at the end of a sentence while looking down to change slides. This is a normal habit that you want to try to break because it undermines your authority a bit (can make it seem like you're less certain about the facts you're presenting at the end, even when you're not).
Q6: I didn't like the slides with the back background. That's a personal preference thing, but if you're going to choose the black background, you need to stick with it and not include tables with a white background. In addition, the slides, while uncluttered, had very few pictures and almost all text. It's nice to break things up with figures and images.
Q8: The seminar was well organized and flowed well. If you really wanted questions from the audience at the midway point, it would have been nice to pause longer (it takes a while to compose a question in our minds before we're willing to ask). Alternatively, you could have done away with the midstream questions pause and taken them all at the end.
Q10: You summarized the studies well, but didn't mention much about whether they were appropriately powered (or of appropriate size). The strengths and limitations mentioned were generally thoughtful, but could have used just a little more analysis (for example, whether the studies really were relevant to the US population or not, and how that impacts what we can learn from them).
Q12: I felt that this was the weakest point of the seminar. Since the data did not support a strong conclusion in terms of prophylactic treatment of PSD, it would have been nice to give some broader take-home message that your colleagues could use (like addressing the question of clopidogrel/SSRI contraindications).
Q19: Great job with a tough topic, Angela! Thank you.

Q4: Just a bit slow at times in transitions between slides
Q8: Very good introduction. / Needs to work on transitions between different slide topics.
Q10: Strong presentation of study data, although the data was not our normal prospective placebo controlled clinical trial.
Q14: Answered the majority of questions very well.
Q16: Joel did a very good job on this seminar.

Q4: A bit quick in delivery at times.
Q6: Left the flood lights over the slides on during the entire seminar making the slides difficult to read.
Q10: Very good presentation of the clinical data.
Q12: Very good conclusions which agreed with the data.
Q16: Knowledge base on SVT was very good.
Q19: Very good seminar with only minor changes needed.

Q4: Angela was nervous at the beginning of the seminar
Q6: Timing of her presentation was spot on!!!
Q8: Mechanism is not well described of SSRIs for Post CVA recovery.  Seemed to skip over this a bit.  If not confident in this then leave out or say this is not well described.
Q12: Would have liked to see you commit to a drug, dose, schedule for one or more of the SSRIs in this treatment.
Q14: F/U study was very good to add.
Q19: Overall, a good seminar with nerves playing a role in delivery and not as specific recommendations as would like to see.

Q6: Pathophysiology slides should be in a pictorial format--not words. / Handouts needed more pictures, not just words.
Q8: This was the best part of the presentation.
Q12: Robert's knowledge of the topic came out here.
Q16: Strong presentation, but with issues on slides and handouts.
Q19: Robert's knowledge of the topic was excellent.  His presentation style was confident.  He needs to work on the handout and slides to make them more user friendly.  He needs to work on his transitions between points in the presentation.

Q4: You  had a nice pace and presentation style.
Q6: The slides were clear overall, but many were too busy (too much on each slide) and several had some mistakes or odd wording. Rather than reproducing a detailed table from a paper, it's better to re-make the table to highlight just the details that are important for your presentation. This is particularly a problem in the "Results by Baseline ICS Use" slide.
Q8: Your interest in the subject was obvious and added a nice personal touch. The objectives were vague and qualitative - hard to determine whether each listener met each objective. For the background information, it seemed that some numbers were added without much thought to what they mean. In particular, the prevalence of asthma in children: presenting absolute prevalence without relative prevalence makes it hard to put into context. If you had known that 59,000 pediatric asthma patients corresponded to about 6.7% of Utah children or that 7.1 million US pediatric asthma patients corresponds to 9.5% of children in the US, that would have been very useful. Also worth considering why Utah rates are lower. Is that a statistically significant difference?
Q10: I felt that the discussion of the study that led to the black box warning was a bit confusing. Based on what you presented, it seemed that the study was fatally flawed and should not have led to the warning. But clearly the FDA thought the risk was significant enough to warrant it.  /  / Also, based on the death rate in that study (~1:1000), you would not expect to see any deaths in any of the pediatric studies you discussed subsequently. But you made a big deal of the fact that there were no deaths. This does not seem to be clinically significant or relevant. If the studies were large enough that you might expect to see some deaths, then you could draw some conclusions about this.
Q12: I would have liked to see a much stronger recommendation to your colleagues based on these studies. First, do you think the black box warning was given in error? A community of pharmacists could rally and play a role in getting the warning removed if the evidence truly supports this action. Second, you suggest that we "counsel both patients and parents about any potential concerns about the black box warning" - what does this mean? Would you proactively discuss this with patients or wait until they ask? What would you tell them?
Q14: Based on your personal interest in the subject, I expected a deeper and broader level of knowledge about the topic.
Q16: See previous comment. It's probably wise to avoid going into detail about your own asthma experiences when talking with patients if those personal experiences include significant non-adherence and spotty checkups! I'd imagine it's much more useful to tell a patient "Yes, I have asthma, and even though it's difficult sometimes, I follow my dosing schedule as close as possible and see my doctor regularly". If the truth is "Yes, I have asthma, and often miss doses and haven't seen my doctor in years", it's better to keep that to yourself. Because the patient will see that and think - here's a medical professional who seems healthy and doesn't do what the doctor says - why should I worry about strict adherence?
Q19: Interesting topic choice, clear personal interest. I liked the way you showed the data leading to the black box warning and additional studies indicating that LABAs may be safe. A more rigorous analysis of the data, coupled with a broader knowledge of the general subject and excluding detrimental personal experiences would have strengthened the seminar and the conclusions we can take from it.

Q4: Shayley demonstrated very good pace and professionalism with her presentation.  Clearly, practice her content.
Q6: Handouts seemed very polished and professional.  Did not see any typos or grammar errors.  Good use of graphics.
Q8: Shayley did very good job with the overall presentation content.  As an audience member it was difficult, at the beginning to remember that SVT was superficial venous thrombosis and not supraventricular tachycardia.  I cannot think of a better way to abbreviate superficial venous thrombosis, but it took some getting used to.
Q10: I have good confidence in Shayley's ability to critique the literature.  I think she achieved balance between packing details into the written handout and orally discussing those details with particular relevance to the controversy.
Q12: Part of the difficulty with this section is that one of the studies was for a drug that is not approved for use in the US.  Automatically, that causes some pause and reflection on how, exactly, that impacts pharmacy practice.  I suppose it is something to watch for.  Generally, I think Shayley did a very good job organizing and discussing approaches to therapy on this particular controversy.
Q14: Had a couple of I'll get back to you responses, but I think she did a good job responding to questions.
Q16: Yes, Shayley demonstrated good overall knoweldge on the subject.  Still not completely sure how to process the information on the non-US drug.
Q19: Shayley make a very good presentation.  Clear that she had great coaching and mentoring from Dr. Vasquez.  In addition, Shayley embraced the serious nature of seminar and made a very good demonstration of her maturing professional skills.  Well Done.

Q4: Joel did a good job with his style.  He came across as slightly anxious during the presentation.  Tended to stand right at podium and read from slide notes on the computer.  Although I feel he knew his material very well, he could have benefitted from practicing the presentation multiple times prior to actual delivery.  Oral presentation is a difficult social event, but repeated practice does help.
Q6: Instructional materials were put together well.  Did not identify typos or other grammar errors that detracted from content.  Did  a pretty good job orienting audience to graphics / state maps.
Q8: Joel provided a very informative and though provoking seminar.  I think he choose a controversy that has clinical relevance, but is also highly relevant to social science and public policy.  These discussion always provide lots of gray areas and lend themselves to great discussion.
Q10: Joel handled the studies pretty well.  The studies all seemed quite different in their methodologies and what their outcomes were.  Accordingly, there was increased difficulty relating these back to the controversy.  I think Joel could have utilized the concept of discussing how each study contributed to a particulary objective of the presentation.  I think that is was Joel was trying to do.  However, with audience members, such as myself, who are somewhat slow, it is best to be obvious and overt with the relationship of study info to presentation objective.
Q12: Seems like the big impact/role for the pharmacist was to become more aware of the issue and possibly politically active on this topic.  Also, possibly to advocate for these items being BTC and an opportunity for pharmacist to educate.
Q14: Not as a fault to Joel, but the audience generally ran away with questions.  I think that reflects the ethical dilemmas presented in this topic.  It also shows this is an area that pharmacy could make a tremendous impact.  Overally, Joel did good with the question session.
Q16: Joel has a good knowledge base on this topic.  Some other areas identified during the q/a session include storage and temperature excursions.  These would also be good to incorporate into the presentation if it is presented again.
Q19: Joel did a very good job with this seminar.  His materials looked very good.  He provided great opportunities for thoughtful discussion.  Only significant opportunity to improve is practicing the presentation delivery and eye contact with the audience.  However, I think Joel has potential to be a good presenter.

Q4: Interesting and informative introduction.  Good audience level.
Q6: Study 2 table was "too busy" but provided a great orientation to it.  A few typos in the slides.
Q8: Very well-organized over all.  Had an appropriate amount of background into the subject.  I would have liked a bit more information on the controversy to be provided in the handout.  Minimal reliance on slides.  Would have liked a bit more of a pause between studies.
Q10: Excellent overview of the clinical information provided.  I liked provision of clinical definitions.
Q12: Good pharmacist recommendations and also thee impact on the pharmacy profession.
Q14: Set the tone for a good discussion.  Answered questions with ease.
Q16: Excellent knowledge base on the topic.
Q19: Very well prepared and provided a good overview, description of studies, and provided well thought-out conclusions.

Q4: Moderate pace and good eye contact with minimal reliance on notes.  Was very professional.  Nervousness showed at first but this got better as the seminar progressed.
Q6: Very good handout and slides - easy to follow.  Good strong controversial case.
Q8: The student showed her interest in the topic and was very clear on providing the controversy of type 1 DM patients' use of GLP-1 analogs.
Q10: Excellent of the clinical information and clinical data.  Excellent as thoroughly explaining each part of the studies.
Q12: Made strong statement against use of GLP-1 agents in type 1.  Presented the overall role of the pharmacist in treatment and care.
Q14: One of the best seminars I have ever attended.
Q16: The preparation Laila demonstrated was excellent - she has an excellent knowledge base and is able to think on her feet very nicely.
Q19: Excellent topic that was thoroughly presented in the studies.  This topic may impact thousands of individuals.
